user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ws_receive_frame:
```c
static unsigned char *
ws_receive_frame (unsigned char *frame, ssize_t *length, int *type)
{
  unsigned char masks[4];
  unsigned char mask;
  unsigned char *msg;
  unsigned char flength;
  unsigned char idx_first_mask;
  unsigned char idx_first_data;
  size_t data_length;
  int i;
  int j;

  msg = NULL;
  if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME;
    idx_first_mask = 2;
    mask = frame[1];
    flength = mask & 0x7F;
    if (flength == 126)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 4;
    }
    else if (flength == 127)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 10;
    }
    idx_first_data = (unsigned char) (idx_first_mask + 4);
    data_length = (size_t) *length - idx_first_data;
    masks[0] = frame[idx_first_mask + 0];
    masks[1] = frame[idx_first_mask + 1];
    masks[2] = frame[idx_first_mask + 2];
    masks[3] = frame[idx_first_mask + 3];
    msg = malloc (data_length + 1);
    if (NULL != msg)
    {
      for (i = idx_first_data, j = 0; i < *length; i++, j++)
      {
        msg[j] = frame[i] ^ masks[j % 4];
      }
      *length = (ssize_t) data_length;
      msg[j] = '\0';
    }
  }
  else if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME;
  }
  else
  {
    *type = frame[0] & 0x0F;
  }
  return msg;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function ws_receive_frame:
#define WS_FIN 128
...
#define WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME 1
...
#define WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME 8
...
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct WsData *ws = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = ws->urh;
  unsigned char buf[2048];
  unsigned char *msg;
  char *text;
  ssize_t got;
  int type;
  int i;

  make_blocking (ws->sock);
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (ws->sock, (void *) buf, sizeof (buf), 0);
    if (0 >= got)
    {
      break;
    }
    msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
    if (NULL == msg)
    {
      break;
    }
    if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)
    {
      ssize_t sent;
      int buf_size;
      buf_size = snprintf (NULL, 0, "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg);
      if (0 < buf_size)
      {
        text = malloc ((size_t) buf_size + 1);
        if (NULL != text)
        {
          if (snprintf (text, (size_t) buf_size + 1,
                        "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg) == buf_size)
            sent = ws_send_frame (ws->sock, text, (size_t) buf_size);
          else
            sent = -1;
          free (text);
        }
        else
          sent = -1;
      }
      else
        sent = -1;
      free (msg);
      if (-1 == sent)
      {
        break;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    if (CLIENT_SOCKS[i] == ws->sock)
    {
      CLIENT_SOCKS[i] = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      break;
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (ws);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The check for WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME inside the final else is unreachable. ws_receive_frame only returns a non-NULL msg when frame[0] matches (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME) (and only then *type is set to WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME). For close or other opcodes ws_receive_frame leaves msg NULL and the caller immediately breaks on if (NULL == msg). Therefore, after that NULL check, type cannot be WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME, so the nested if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME) { free(msg); break; } can never be reached. This violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (no unreachable code).
